description:
Carnobacterium maltaromaticum is a species of gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic bacteria that belongs to the genus Carnobacterium. It is a non-spore-forming, catalase-positive, and psychrotrophic (cold-tolerant) bacterium.

Carnobacterium maltaromaticum is commonly found in various food environments, such as meat, fish, and dairy products, where it can contribute to the development of desirable flavors and aroma compounds. It is considered a member of the lactic acid bacteria (LAB) group, as it is capable of producing lactic acid as a primary fermentation product.

This species is known for its ability to grow at low temperatures, making it well-adapted to thrive in refrigerated or chilled food products. Carnobacterium maltaromaticum has been studied for its potential use as a biopreservative, as it can inhibit the growth of pathogenic and spoilage bacteria in food systems through the production of antimicrobial substances, such as bacteriocins.

Overall, Carnobacterium maltaromaticum is an important member of the microbial community in various food environments and has potential applications in the food industry due to its ability to contribute to flavor development and food preservation.
